content.webTitle: The New York Dolls play 'mock rock' on British TV

fields.headline: The New York Dolls play 'mock rock' on British TV
fields.bodyText: The Dolls' appearance on the Old Grey Whistle Test kickstarted the war between punks and hippies three years early. Before filming, Dolls frontman David Johansen told presenter Bob Harris he had "bunny teeth"; following the Dolls' vigorous mime through Jet Boy, Harris sniggered into camera and pronounced the band "mock rock". Among the few viewers outraged by Harris's dismissal was a young Mancunian, one Steven Morrissey, on whom the Dolls would have a profound effect (when the three surviving members reunited in 2004 it was at Morrissey's behest; he had been president of their fan club). Today, Harris's comment seems more affectionate than disrespectful, but his card had been marked. In March 1977, at the height of punk, Harris was assaulted by a refreshed Sid Vicious; a year later, Harris exited the Test, replaced by the altogether more punk-friendly Annie Nightingale.
